awd_titl_txt: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Scholars
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program will support the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Oakton Community College in Illinois. This project aims to award a total of 127 yearly scholarships to at least 47 academically talented, financially needy students pursuing degrees in mathematics, physical sciences, biological sciences, engineering or related technologies, or computer science and technology. The project will provide cohort learning experiences, a STEM/English learning community and STEM philosophy course, proactive advising, and faculty mentoring. Scholars will also have opportunities to participate in undergraduate research projects and paid internships.
 
The program is designed to remove some of the barriers that students encounter while enrolled in challenging STEM coursework through a holistic program of supportive services and STEM engagement. It will use the latest best practices for STEM student engagement and retention to develop novel programming focused on supporting low income students in STEM fields, as well as unifying existing support services and activities. Further, by using more intentional recruitment strategies this program also seeks to broaden the pool of STEM Scholars. Understanding the impact of this comprehensive approach at the community college level will contribute to the current knowledge base about effective practices in STEM student success. The knowledge generated by this project may be applicable to other community colleges as they develop strategies to recruit, engage, retain, and graduate and/or transfer STEM students. Collaboration with district high schools through the project?s Advisory Committee will promote shared best practices throughout the district. The STEM Scholars program has the potential to serve as a model that could be implemented by other colleges to improve STEM engagement and retention.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Oakton College in Illinois. This project aimed to award scholarships benefiting academically talented, financially needy students pursuing degrees in mathematics, physical sciences, biological sciences, engineering and related technologies, and computer science and technology. In addition to providing scholarships, the project focused on providing program participants with cohort learning experiences, proactive advising, opportunities to participate in undergraduate research projects and paid internships, and faculty mentoring.

The STEM Scholars Program was designed to remove some of the barriers that students encounter while enrolled in challenging STEM coursework through a holistic program of supportive services and STEM engagement. It used the latest best practices for STEM student engagement and retention to develop novel programming focused on supporting low income students in STEM fields. Further, when possible, it utilized more intentional recruitment strategies to broaden the pool of STEM Scholars. The intention of the program was to understand the impact of this holistic approach at the community college level to contribute to the current knowledge base of effective practices in STEM student success.

The STEM Scholars Program has demonstrated how collaborative efforts between academic and support services improve the persistence and transfer of underrepresented students in STEM at a community college. The program's holistic support model has modestly improved persistence rates among underrepresented participant groups (except females) and dramatically improved persistence for the Hispanic/Latin X participant group by 12% (Table 1). Additionally, 37% of STEM Scholars transferred to four-year institutions; significantly higher than the 12% transfer rate of the comparison cohort (Table 2).

Despite scalability challenges, the program's model offers valuable insights for institutional changes necessary to support future cohorts of STEM students. The research conducted based on program results finds that cross-functional teams played a crucial role in identifying and addressing academic, enrollment, financial, and personal challenges, effectively identifying and mitigating potential roadblocks to persistence. This collaborative model ensured students received the necessary support to succeed and allowed practitioners to simultaneously identify and address institutional barriers through collective action. Although scaling this model poses challenges, the members of the leadership team learned through the implementation of this program that a team-based approach to student support is required to meet the complicated and diverse needs of STEM students in a community college setting to support their persistence in STEM curricula as they work toward STEM transfer and employment.

The STEM Scholars program can serve as a model for the college to employ more broadly among all STEM students to improve STEM engagement and retention. The knowledge generation developed as a result of this project may be utilized by other community colleges as they develop strategies to recruit, engage, retain, and graduate and/or transfer STEM students. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/09/2025
Modified by: Suzanne Ziegenhorn
